thread.title: College Football Game Day: MSU at Concordia-St. Paul, Gustavus at St. John's
thread.title_full: College Football Game Day: MSU at Concordia-St. Paul, Gustavus at St. John's

author: ccourrier@mankatofreepress.com(Chad Courrier)
title: College Football Game Day: MSU at Concordia-St. Paul, Gustavus at St. John's
text:
Minnesota State at Concordia-St. Paul 
Noon, St. Paul, 1230-AM The Fan 
First down: No. 1-ranked Minnesota State (6-0, 2-0 in South Division) plays at Concordia-St. Paul (1-5, 0-2) today in a Northern Sun Intercollegiate Conference game. The Mavericks defeated Augustana 35-27 last week, while the Golden Bears lost 52-20 to Upper Iowa. ... Minnesota State leads the series 7-2 with four straight victories. Last season, the Mavericks won 38-6 at Blakeslee Stadium. The Mavericks are 3-1 at St. Paul, including a 27-7 win in 2013. ... Minnesota State has won the last 19 games at an opponent’s stadium. 
Second down: Sophomore receiver Ty Dennis had a career-high of 153 yards receiving against Augustana with two touchdowns. He has 17 receptions for a team-best 429 yards and five touchdowns. He’s averaging 25.2 yards per catch, which leads the Northern Sun and ranks fourth in Division II. ... Senior running back Connor Thomas won’t play today because of injury. He is second in the conference with 619 yards rushing, and he’s scored seven touchdowns. ... Receiver Kyle Riggott leads Division II in punt returns with a 25.4-yard average. 
Third down: Defensive end Josh Gordon was the Northern Sun’s defensive player of the week again after making four sacks against Augustana. He has had four sacks in a game three times in his career. Gordon also had eight tackles and two forced fumbles. Gordon is third on the team with 31 tackles that includes 15 tackles for loss and 9.5 sacks. He ranks fifth in Division II for sacks and tackles for loss. ... The defense had eight sacks against Augustana and has 23 sacks on the season. ... Defensive tackle Jeffrey Raymond will miss today’s game because of injury. He is 10th on the defense with 17 tackles, with three tackles for loss and one sack. ... The defense is allowing only 63.2 yards rushing and 1.9 yard per attempt. The Mavericks rank second in Division II in rush defense and fourth in total defense (225.0 yards per game). 
Fourth down: Concordia-St. Paul has lost its last three games by a combined 116 points. ... The Golden Bears are averaging 16.7 points per game, while giving up 36.8 points per game. ... Alex Carr is the top rusher with 235 rushing yards. ... Ben Schramski has completed 66 of 136 passes for 777 yards and five touchdowns with four interceptions. ... Alquawn Vickers and Jason Oney each have 21 receptions. ... Jordan Halverson has a team-high 58 tackles, and Josh Trifunov has made seven sacks. DeCeon Schumann has two interceptions. 
Extra point: Minnesota State kicker Alden Haffar ranks fifth in the Northern Sun in scoring with 51 points, coming on eight field goals and 27 PATs. He is 8 of 14 on field goals with a long of 52 yards. Haffar is averaging 43.8 yards per punt, which would lead the Northern Sun if he had more attempts. He had punts of 51 and 59 yards in the second half last week that changed field position. After the 59-yarder was downed at the Augustana 8, the Mavericks forced a fumble that led to a touchdown. 
Gustavus Adolphus at St. John’s 
1 p.m., Collegeville, KNUJ 860-AM 
First down: The No. 20-rated Gusties (6-0, 4-0 in MIAC) play at No. 15 St. John’s (4-1, 2-1). The Gusties defeated St. Olaf 58-34 last week, and the Johnnies, who had a bye last week, downed Hamline 41-21 on Oct. 3. ... The Johnnies lead the series 46-32-3 and have won 26 of the last 28 games. Last season, the Johnnies defeated the Gusties 29-19 at Hollingsworth Stadium. The last time the Gusties defeated the Johnnies at Collegeville was 1997. 
Second down: Quarterback Mitch Hendricks has passed for 2,009 yards and 23 touchdowns, both of which lead Division III. Last week, he broke the program record for touchdown passes when he threw for five. He has 67 touchdown passes in his career, breaking the previous mark of 65 set by Jordan Stolp (2004-07). Hendricks has 7,350 yards passing in his career and has a chance to threaten Stolp’s record of 8,496. ... Matt Boyce ranks second in Division III with 820 yards receiving and 11 touchdown receptions. For his career, Boyce has 2,797 yards receiving and needs to average 96 yards in the remaining four games to pass the record of 3,180 by Chad Arlt (2005-08). ... Jake Douglas had the best performance by a Gustavus tight end in more than 35 years last week when he caught nine passes for 172 yards and three touchdowns. He was named the MIAC offensive player of the week and was named to the D3football.com team of the week. ... The Gusties are converting third downs at 66.2 percent (51 of 77), which is the best in all of college football. Gustavus is 7 of 7 in fourth-down conversions. 
Third down: Gustavus is allowing 20.3 points, 144.7 yards rushing and 210.3 yards passing per game. ... Linebacker Kysten Zierke leads the defense with 45 tackles, three more than linebacker Anders Raarup. ... The Gusties have made 17 sacks, with Isaac Kotilla leading the team with 4.5 sacks. Casey Decker and Chris Nelson each have 2.5 sacks. 
Fourth down: St. John’s running back Sam Sura leads the MIAC with 136.2 yards rushing per game. He ranks second in St. John’s history with 3,098 yards. ... Nick Martin has completed 68 of 97 passes for 800 yards and six touchdowns. Josh Bungum has 28 catches for 295 yards and one touchdown, and Nick Simon has 19 catches for 274 yards and three scores. ... Carter Hanson and Drake Matuska lead the defense with 30 tackles. 
Extra point: Gustavus is one of 27 undefeated teams in college football, but the schedule gets tougher in the final month. Through six games, Gustavus’ strength of schedule ranked 132nd out of 247 teams with opponents having a combined record of 11-22. The final four opponents have a combined record of 18-4 with St. John’s, Bethel, Concordia and St. Thomas all having been ranked in the top 20 at some point this season. 
Compiled by Free Press staff writer Chad Courrier.
